docTitle.titlePart:
ORGANIC CHEMISTRY
STUDY OF THE REACTIVITY OF AMMONIUM CARBOXYLATES IN THE SYNTHESIS
OF AMIDES UNDER HIGH-PRESSURE DEFORMATION CONDITIONS

byline.docAuthor: N. P. Chistotina and A. A. Zharov

front.div:
On deformation under pressures up to I0 GPa the ammonium salts of aliphatic and aro-
matic acids~ as well as mixtures of a free carboxylic acid with the ~mmonium salts of
strong mineral acids, are converted into the corresponding amides.
The amide yields
increase with pressure, the magnitude of shearing deformation, and temperature.
The temperature and pressure coefficients for amide formation are low and have values of
2.5-4 kJ/mole and --i to --2 cm3/mole, respectively.
The reactivity of ammonium salts
in the synthesis of amides alternates in the homologous series of aliphatic acids in
a similar way to the shear stress of these salts. The reactivity of the ammonium salts
of aliphatic acids increases when the reaction is conducted in a matrix of an ammonium
salt which possesses plasticity and a high shear stress.
At present it has been established that under shearing deformation conditions under high
pressure (DC + HP) chemical reactions take place in solid substances at great velocities, the
degree of conversion of the substances being a function of the shearing deformation [i]. There
are numerous demonstrations that the physical properties of the substances, such as plastic-
ity and shear stress, have an effect on a chemical process under DC + HP [2].
With the purpose of studying therelationships in the chemical reactions of organic com-
pounds under DS + HP we have undertaken an investigation into the formation of amides from am-
monium carboxylates.
A high temperature is usually required for the conversion of ammonium
salts into acid amides but under DS + HP conditions amides may be formed at room temperature
